Here is the first one. It alone took me probably 4 hours to write (including the amount of time to read the article a couple of times to understand it).
 
 
 
The newly discovered gene Rfpl4 (which encodes the protein RFPL4) is expressed only in germ cells and plays a key role in regulating the meiotic cell cycle in mammalian oocytes. 
 
 Progression through the meiotic cell cycle is regulated by fluctuations in the cytoplasmic concentration of a protein called MPF, for maturation-promoting factor. MPF is a heterodimer composed of a cell-cycle protein called cyclin B1 and a second protein known as a cdk (cyclin-dependent kinase). One important method of controlling the concentration of active MPF is by regulating the amount of cyclin B1 present in the cytosol. When cyclin B1 synthesis is accelerated, the protein accumulates in the cytoplasm and binds with the cdk causing an accumulation of MPF, setting one stage of the cell cycle in motion. But, the MPF must then be deactivated in order to trigger the next stage. This can be accomplished by the degradation of cyclin B1 through a process called ubiquitination.
 
 The major pathway for controlled protein degradation in eukaryotic cells is ubiquitination. In this process, the target protein is enzymatically tagged with many ubiquitin molecules, which then serve as a signal for the cell's proteasomes to degrade the protein. The class of enzymes that physically tag target proteins with ubiquitin are called E3 proteins; these ubiquitin ligase proteins are numerous and are the component of the system that supplies the specificity (i.e., how a specific protein is selected as a target for degradation). E3 proteins obtain their ubiquitin molecules from one of a few types of E2 proteins. 
 
 Returning to mammalian meiosis, oocytes are arrested twice. Before ovulation, oocytes arrest in prophase I. Later, ovulation causes them to progress to metaphase II, where they are arrested again (until fertilization). The concentration of cyclin B1 has been found to correlate with specific stages in meiosis: it accumulates just prior to metaphase (both I and II) and is degraded during the transition from metaphase to anaphase (both I and II). Combined with the fact that cyclin B1 is one of the two components of MPF, it is clear that regulation of cyclin B1 plays a key role in progression through meiosis.
 
 In mammalian oocytes, the RFPL4 protein was found to interact with an E2 enzyme called HR6A, as well as with ubiquitin B, cyclin B1, and a subunit on proteasomes. Experiments to detect RFPL4 in early embryos showed a lower concentration in the two-cell stage relative to the oocyte, and an absence of RFPL4 in the eight-cell stage (RFPL4 may itself become a 'victim' of regulated degradation via ubiquitination).
 
 The newly discovered, germ-cell specific, RFPL4 protein has been found capable of forming a 'bridge' between the various components of a ubiquitin degradation complex: it can interact with an E2 "ubiquitin-presenting" enzyme, the ubiquitin molecule itself, regions of proteasomes, and the cell-cycle-regulating protein targeted for degradation, cyclin B1. These interactions clearly suggest that RFPL4 is a ubiquitin ligase protein. Further, RFPL4 shares a protein domain common among E3 enzymes. Hence, RFPL4 is a germ-cell specific, E3 enzyme that plays a key role in regulating the meiotic cell cycle in mammalian oocytes.
